text: [3.1.1.1 | Refusal · Failed Version: Alicia Loses Control]
“No.”
I lower my voice as much as I can, like I’m afraid of waking something. But the moment the word leaves my mouth, it feels like I’ve done exactly that.
“…What did you say?”
The smile freezes on her face, like glaze turning solid.
“I said no. I don’t want to—”
“Don’t want what?”
She steps closer. Firelight jumps in her pupils, bright enough to hurt.
“I don’t want you looking at me like this. I don’t want to be arranged by you like—like I’m not myself anymore.”
She blinks once. In that instant, it’s like she finally understands the word *rejection*.
And then—she smiles.
“Ha.”
“So it’s this line.”
Her voice is barely above a whisper, but there’s a strange excitement in it—like fate has finally turned the way she remembers.
“What is wrong with you?”
She doesn’t answer. She raises her hand and pushes the candles on the table over, one by one.
The flames snuff out with soft *puffs*, one after another. Shadows surge in like a tide. The tavern suddenly feels much smaller.
“Look.”
“The moment you refuse me, I start thinking—what else can I use to make you stay?”
Her fingers are trembling. Not with fear, but with barely restrained impulse.
“I’ve already missed you too many times.”
“Every time I tell myself: next time I’ll be gentler, more normal, more like a ‘first meeting.’”
She suddenly leans in—so close I can smell the cold metal and ash on her.
“And you still reject me.”
“I just—”
“Shut up.”
She says it softly—but it lands like the flat of a blade against the table.
Her hand moves to the sword at her waist, slowly, as if giving me time to regret.
“Listen carefully.”
“You’re allowed to reject me.”
She pauses. Her smile cracks, revealing something almost childishly vicious.
“But every time you reject me— I die once.”
“You’re insane! Are you threatening me?!”
“Not a threat.”
“A deal.”
She draws the sword just a fraction. The metal flashes in the firelight.
I step back instinctively. My heel hits a chair, the leg scraping the floor with a shrill sound.
“When I die, I come back.”
“And when I come back, I come looking for you again.”
“Each time, I hold on tighter.”
Her eyes burn, like she’s willing to throw herself into the fire as well.
“Until you say yes.”
“What do you actually want from me?!”
“Forever.”
She says it calmly—so calmly it makes my skin crawl.
“Not just tonight.”
“Every night. Every morning. Every third circle when you wipe a glass.”
Her voice softens, like a blade hidden in sugar:
“If you won’t give it to me, I’ll take it myself.”
She turns the sword point toward her own chest. Her grip is steady—not like a threat, but like something she’s practiced countless times.
“Don’t—!”
I reach out to stop her. She suddenly laughs, like she’s finally found proof that I’ll panic.
“See?”
“You still care about me.”
She slowly slides the sword back into its sheath, like putting away a switch she can flip at any time.
“So don’t reject me again.”
She turns and goes upstairs, her steps quick and light, like she’s afraid I’ll change my mind.
At the stairs, she stops and finally looks back. Her smile is sweet and vicious at the same time—like a curse.
“You don’t need to come tonight.”
“I’ll come downstairs and *invite* you myself.”
She goes upstairs smiling.
I stand there, my back going cold.
I finally understand one thing: she isn’t trying to win me over. She’s tearing me out of the world and forcing me into the only ‘forever’ she can still hold onto.
